title: Office worker crushed to death at his desk by tyres falling through roof
text:
A DHL worker was crushed to death by a pile of tyres (Picture: Getty)

An office worker was crushed to death when a stack of tyres came crashing through the roof.

Robert Baynham, 50, was trapped beneath two half tonne wheels which toppled from where they were stored and fell through the ceiling.

The married dad was rushed to hospital but died of multiple injuries on February 2, 2016.

Logistics giant DHL has now been fined £2.6 million for health and safety breaches.

A court heard no risk assessment had been put in place by the firm where there was a ‘focus on product movement rather than health and safety.’

Three other workers were also injured, one severely, during the freak accident at the firm’s tyre distribution centre in Coventry.

Logistics giant DHL has now been fined £2.6 million for health and safety breaches (Stock picture: Getty)

DHL Services Ltd pleaded guilty to failing to carry out a risk assessment and failing to ensure the safety of employees at Warwick Crown Court.

The company was fined yesterday for what Mr Justice Jeremy Baker described as a ‘high degree of culpability’ for a ‘serious corporate failure.’

He said: ‘The immediate cause of the stack toppling over is unclear, but not only was it comprised of different sizes of tyres, the handling driver was in the process of constructing a similar stack which may have led to some contact with it.

‘Although there may have been an individualised failure to make a proper risk assessment, there was a corporate failure to do so.

‘There is no question that these failures have led to a human tragedy.

‘Robert Baynham was a family man, having met his wife of 30 years when they were teenagers.

‘His death has deprived their children of their father.’

The judge said DHL, with £1.4 billion annual turnover, had two previous health and safety convictions in 2017 and 2018.

Prosecutor Bernard Thorogood said the company had ‘failed to conduct its own risk assessment and failed to discharge its health and safety duties.’

Mr Thorogood said the tyres were held in stillages (metal frames) in which tyres of different types were contained.

A ‘tall and heavy stack’ of eight cross-stocked stillages had been placed next to an office in which Mr Baynham, John Knight, Bernard Halpin and Jason Gordon were working.

Mr Thorogood said: ‘The risks of forming stacks of stillages are obvious, and the company knew of previous topples.

‘Past events showed this is a well-established risk and should have been factored into the defendant company’s consideration.

‘All four individuals in the office were at serious risk of losing their lives.’

Mr Knight, aged 35, suffered three fractures to his skull, a brain bleed, eight fractured ribs, a fractured collarbone and sternum, and spent two weeks in hospital.

The other two men were less seriously injured and discharged after treatment, but still deal with the incident’s effects, the court was told.
